Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Capacity building in Cybersecurity-literacy: An inter-disciplinary approach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The demand for cybersecurity research and a trained cybersecurity workforce is significant and increasing daily. The goal of this collaborative project between the University of Nevada, Reno (UNR) and the Truckee Meadows Community College (TMCC) is to develop an interdisciplinary cybersecurity research and education platform. This effort is aimed towards the development of the next generation of cybersecurity scientists and professionals and to equip them with a solid grasp of different academic viewpoints, including Computer Science, Political Science, Social Psychology, Information Systems, Business, Public Policy, and Justice. The research team will have a significant impact on students through engaging interdisciplinary training and learning mechanisms. The project has both a direct and indirect impact on hands-on research, STEM education, training and career development of the graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 students and ultimately, the community.

Through this project, students will (1) learn the theory and application of cybersecurity from an interdisciplinary perspective; (2) use interactive learning materials and tools; and (3) engage in hands-on transformative experiences through cyber-games and state-of-the-art testbeds. The main contribution of the project is to develop instructional modules that can be incorporated in a variety of courses by fostering a holistic approach towards cybersecurity through collaboration across disciplines. The project brings faculty from different disciplines together to develop modular library packages while keeping each major's background in mind and also adopt them seamlessly into the learning environment of each discipline. The modular nature of the developed library packages and replicable teaching materials and activities will help in wide dissemination and usage throughout the nation. This project will assist in sustaining long-term research/education partnerships and will nurture a workforce of cybersecurity professionals who will be able to integrate technical, legal, psychological, political and financial aspects of cybersecurity into a practical, secure and dependable cyberspace.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major key outcome of this project is that it has helped us to create an engaging and interactive cybersecurity education launch pad and stimulate learning across many disciplines. This project used unique interdisciplinary curriculum to improve cybersecurity literacy and encourage student enrollment and research in cybersecurity related fields. The project created and distributed twenty curriculum modules covering topics in the areas of Information Assurance, Legal Issues, Human Factors and Technical Aspects. These curriculum modules were designed to be used in existing courses in technical areas such as computer science and information systems, as well as non-technical areas such as political science, law and business. The modules provided students with a broader perspective of cybersecurity issues and encouraged study of non-technical cybersecurity topics. It also provided opportunities for students in non-technical disciplines to learn basic technical cybersecurity concepts.

To adapt a holistic cybersecurity curriculum approach, we have not only focused on theoretical concepts but also have focused on hands-on systems development. A state-of-the-art sandbox for cybersecurity research, training and awareness programs has been now setup and is continuously being updated. With the current testbed, we are able to create sandboxed cybersecurity training environment for the students in the classroom. With multitudes of VMs running, the students can now log into the systems and practice different cybersecurity test exercises in a very secure and isolated manner.

The project had a national impact on cybersecurity literacy as there were 575 downloads of the curriculum modules by individuals from 39 unique institutions. These institutions were primarily two and four-year colleges and universities, but also included two private corporations and one non-profit dedicated to women in technical careers. These institutions were located in 19 different states, representing every region of the country.

The project also had an impact on cybersecurity human resources at the lead institution. As a result of this project, the Cybersecurity Center at the University of Nevada, Reno was expanded to include faculty from criminal justice, psychology, and journalism. The University also hired new faculty in non-technical areas specifically to address cybersecurity in their fields.

In addition, the project had an impact on the development of student technical skills in the area of cyber defense. Sixty students from both participating institutions participated in national cyber security competitions during the course of the project. The cyber competitions encouraged students to expand their technical knowledge beyond classroom topics and develop their problem-solving skills. By sponsoring initial participation in the competitions, the project was able to generate enthusiasm among students and create a sustainable, student supported effort to encourage and support participation in cyber competitions. Students have self-organized to promote participation and have formed study groups to mentor fellow students on technical skills used in the competitions.
